I have looked through the records and, as near as I
can figure, we will only be billing about $2£.00 against
the project. This will account for some phone calls and
miscellaneous items. At that, the estimate is on the
liberal side.
As soon as I finish this letter I*nr taking off for
a two-week tour of duty with the Army in Washington. I
can be reached during this time in the Troop Radio - Tele¬
vision Branch, Office of the Chief of Information, Depart¬
ment of the Army, Washington 25>, D. C. I will return to the
Twin Cities around the iith of July. I have put a note on
my calendar to get a report off to you at once. If things
get dull in Washington, I will work on it during the next
two weeks. It shouldn’t take too long.
As for the billing, if you will drop me a note as to
how much consultation services to include on the bill, I
will get this off to you as soon as I get back in the Twin
Cities. I would appreciate some suggestion as to how this
item might be written up.
While I am in Washington, I will try to get into the
Education Office to talk with some of the "brain trust".
Perhaps by that time they will be talking about a contract.
I am sorry that I could not send you the report before
I left but we have been practically losing our minds trying
to arrange for the prodiction of 390 thirty-minute college
lessons between July 18 and August 26.
John W. Seeger
Neil Sherburne
Loring M. Staples
Harold E. Wood
Cordiall;
Clair R. Tettemer
/Director of School Programs
